title: R45248
content: Under the Congressional Review Act (CRA), agencies must submit a report to Congress and the Government Accountability Office (GAO) before a rule can take effect. Major rules require additional time for Congressional review, and GAO assesses the agency's compliance with procedural steps. Congress can use expedited procedures to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to use expedited procedures to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. The expedited procedures primarily exist in the Senate and include steps such as discharging a Senate committee, making a nondebatable motion to proceed, and holding up to 10 hours of debate before a vote. If both houses pass the joint resolution, it is sent to the President for signature or veto. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. If the President vetoes the resolution, Congress can override the veto. If the resolution is signed by the President or Congress overrides the veto, the rule will not take effect. The rule would be deemed to have had no effect, and the status quo prior to the rule's issuance would be reinstated. Additionally, a rule cannot be issued in a substantially similar form unless authorized by a subsequent law. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. If the President vetoes the resolution, Congress can override the veto. The CRA governs "rules" promulgated by a "federal agency," using the definition of "agency" provided in the APA. The more difficult interpretive issue is what types of agency actions should be considered "rules" under the CRA. The CRA requires agencies to submit actions falling within its definition of a rule to Congress and GAO before they can take effect, including rules from APA notice-and-comment procedures and other agency statements. Section 801(a)(1)(A) of the CRA mandates agencies to submit reports to Congress and the Comptroller General, including a general statement on the rule, its effective date, and details on cost-benefit analysis. GAO assesses compliance with additional requirements for major rules and includes its assessment in the major rule report submitted to House and Senate committees within 15 calendar days. Failure to submit a rule to Congress would prevent the House and Senate from utilizing these special procedures. In hearings in 1997 and 1998, it was noted that agencies were not fully complying with the submission requirement. The GAO has issued 21 opinions on whether certain agency actions qualify as rules eligible for disapproval under the CRA, listing them chronologically. The Emergency Sale Timber Program was enacted to increase salvage timber sales for forest health. A memorandum from the Secretary of Agriculture regarding the program was deemed a rule under the CRA by the GAO. The Department of Agriculture's Forest Service issued the Tongass National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan, which sets management direction for the forest. GAO determined the plan was a rule under the CRA and not excepted under 5 U.S.C. §804(3) because decisions in the plan affect non-agency parties. President Clinton signed Executive Order 13061 related to the American Heritage River Initiative. The American Heritage River Initiative (AHRI) aimed to support communities in restoring and protecting rivers. The President designated 10 rivers for the program. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) determined that Executive Order 13061 was not subject to the Congressional Review Act (CRA) as the President is not considered an "agency" under the CRA. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued guidance on investigating discrimination complaints in environmental permitting, which GAO deemed as affecting non-agency parties and therefore a rule under the CRA. The Farm Credit Administration issued a booklet providing guidance on national charter application processes and territories, which GAO determined to be a legislative rule under the CRA, requiring informal rulemaking procedures. The GAO determined that the Trinity River Record of Decision (ROD) was a rule under the CRA due to its policy-setting nature and broad impact on non-agency parties. The ROD outlined actions to restore anadromous fish in the Trinity River, addressing decreased river flows in the basin. The Department of Veterans Affairs issued a memorandum directing network directors to stop certain marketing activities to enroll new veterans in the VA health care system. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) concluded that the memorandum was not a rule under the Congressional Review Act (CRA) as it was considered a statement of agency procedure or practice that did not affect the rights or obligations of non-agency parties. The VA issued a memorandum terminating the Vendee Loan Program, which allowed loans for the sale of foreclosed VA-guaranteed property. The memorandum was considered a rule relating to agency management and did not substantially affect non-agency parties' rights or obligations. The VA terminated the Vendee Loan Program, a discretionary management decision, which did not impact any party's rights or obligations. In a separate development, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services issued a letter clarifying requirements for the State Children's Health Insurance Program. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) determined that a letter regarding the State Children's Health Insurance Program and an information memorandum about the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program were considered rules under the Congressional Review Act (CRA). The letter and memorandum were deemed as statements with general applicability and future effect, designed to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy. The Environmental Protection Agency issued a proposed rule on greenhouse gas emissions from electric utility generating units on January 8, 2014. The rule aimed to set standards for fossil fuel-fired electric steam generating units. The GAO concluded that the proposed rule on greenhouse gas emissions from steam generating units and combustion turbines was not covered by the CRA, as it only applies to final rules. Additionally, the interagency guidance on leveraged lending was issued on March 22, 2013. The GAO concluded that the leveraged-lending guidance was a rule under the CRA due to its future effect and lack of exceptions. The guidance included principles for safe-and-sound leveraged lending activities for agency-supervised institutions. The Forest Service updated the Tongass Land and Resource Management Plan, which outlined permissible uses in different forest areas. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) determined that the plan amendment was a substantive rule under the Congressional Review Act (CRA), impacting the regulated community. Despite USDA's argument, the plan did not qualify for an exception. Additionally, the Bureau of Land Management issued resource management plans for four areas in Alaska. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) concluded that the Eastern Interior Plan was a rule under the Congressional Review Act (CRA) due to its general applicability and future effect. The plan was designed to implement law and did not fit into any exceptions. On March 21, 2013, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau issued guidance on indirect auto lending compliance with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. The GAO concluded that the bulletin on indirect auto lenders' compliance with fair lending requirements was a rule under the CRA. President Trump issued a memorandum on global health assistance funding. The City Policy prohibits assistance to foreign organizations promoting abortion. The Department of State and USAID issued fact sheets to implement the policy. GAO determined these actions were not rules under the CRA as they were implementing the President's decision. The court held that agency actions implementing President Trump's policy decision were not subject to review under the APA, as it involved policy-making at the highest level by the executive branch. IRS announced it would not accept electronically filed tax returns without ACA reporting requirements. The GAO concluded that the IRS statement regarding health coverage reporting is not a rule under the CRA, as it only changes the timing of compliance measures without affecting taxpayers' rights. The SSA's HALLEX manual outlines how disability benefit claims are processed under the Social Security Act. The SSA's HALLEX manual policy prohibits using Internet information in benefit claim decisions, except for specific procedures. GAO determined these sections are procedural rules exempt from the CRA. IRS issued Revenue Procedure 2018-38 modifying tax-exempt entities' reporting requirements, submitted to Congress under the CRA. Senator Orrin Hatch requested GAO's opinion on the matter. The GAO opinion was sought by Senator Orrin Hatch regarding the IRS's submission of Revenue Procedure 2018-38 under the CRA. The IRS argued that the document was not covered by the CRA, despite submitting it to Congress. This was a unique situation as it was the first time GAO had to consider the application of the CRA in such a case. The GAO opinion addressed whether the submission of the IRS revenue procedure triggered the CRA's timelines, not whether the procedure met the statutory definition of a "rule." GAO stated that since the IRS had already submitted the rule, a GAO opinion on the CRA's applicability was unnecessary. The IRS submission allowed for congressional review under the CRA, enabling Congress to exercise its oversight powers. The GAO concluded that the April 2018 memorandum on zero-tolerance policy for illegal border crossings was not a rule under the CRA as it pertained to agency organization, procedure, or practice, and did not change individuals' rights or obligations. This exception allowed the memorandum to be exempt from the CRA's timelines. In 2018, the Secretary of Commerce justified adding a citizenship question to the 2020 census in a memorandum to the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. The GAO stated that the memorandum was not a rule under the CRA, as it was part of the statutory process for informing Congress of census questions. The GAO stated that the memorandum justifying the citizenship question on the 2020 census did not meet the definition of a "rule" under the CRA.
